awd_titl_txt: EAGER: SaTC-EDU: Artificial Intelligence for Cybersecurity Education via a Machine Learning-Enabled Security Knowledge Graph
awd_abstract_narration:
Cybersecurity education is exceptionally challenging because its learning outcomes often comprise fragmented information that fails to provide learners with adaptive guidance on how to connect and build on the concepts they have learned. This project will develop an artificial intelligence (AI)-enabled cybersecurity tool referred to as a knowledge graph (AISecKG) to address this cybersecurity education challenge. Knowledge graphs, widely used by search engines and social networks,  integrate data and can store linked descriptions of items such as objects, concepts, and events. This project applies a novel learning approach for cybersecurity education by providing university students a flexible learning plan that enhances their critical thinking and problem-solving skills. This approach aims to help students understand the complex nature of cyber-attacks and defense mechanisms, provide them with a holistic view and better prepare them to address the complexities of real-world scenarios. 

The development and deployment of AISecKG are interdisciplinary. First, the project employs machine learning (ML) and AI approaches to build a new cybersecurity knowledge graph by measuring and setting up similarities and dependencies among cybersecurity learning targets for both study planning and learning-outcome assessment. Second, it incorporates a multi-level assessment approach to design cybersecurity curricula, scaffold student cognitive engagement, and improve student learning outcomes. AISecKG has two primary design goals. First, it will guide instructors to develop a problem-based learning curriculum based on their learning objectives. Second, it will allow students to apply an adaptive learning strategy, incorporating hands-on labs to assess their learning outcomes. To assess students’ learning performance quantitatively, AISecKG will (a) deploy an evidence-based model and learning materials for problem-based cybersecurity education focusing on developing teacher capacity and practice while using targeted materials and approaches; (b) produce a productive teaching model for deep learning that promotes a culture of scientific inquiry and design as well as a set of strategies to develop student competency; and (c) provide evidence of student learning outcomes as a pedagogical resource to support student cognitive engagement in learning tasks interactively. 

This project is supported by a special initiative of the Secure and Trustworthy Cyberspace (SaTC) program to foster new, previously unexplored, collaborations between the fields of cybersecurity, artificial intelligence, and education. The SaTC program aligns with the Federal Cybersecurity Research and Development Strategic Plan and the National Privacy Research Strategy to protect and preserve the growing social and economic benefits of cyber systems while ensuring security and privacy.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Developing a skilled cybersecurity workforce is essential for national security in the digital age. Traditional education systems need to keep pace with evolving threats and diverse learning requirements. Cybersecurity Education is problem-based learning that involves solving complex, multifaceted, real-world problems that demand an adaptive learning strategy with tangible feedback and assessments to motivate students to learn and manage their learning progress. This project aimed to enhance cybersecurity education by creating novel AI-based tools for interactive learning and developing a systemic approach to assess the student's perception and learning process. We proposed creating an AI-enabled security knowledge graph AISecKG to teach cybersecurity. We made the following contributions to the project. To develop AI tools for cognitively engaging students, we created AI-based knowledge graphs (AISecKG) for the coursework for our university students. We first developed an ontology, AISecKG, to build AI systems for students and novice learners in the cybersecurity education domain. We then proposed an end-to-end framework to extract cybersecurity-related entities and build knowledge graphs from the course lab instruction manuals. A language model was trained to extract cybersecurity-named entities from public texts and educational material on cybersecurity. We also developed a triple dataset to develop cybersecurity knowledge graphs. The knowledge graphs provide a visual graph for complex cybersecurity concepts and help break down task instructions to analyze and implement the project's challenges visually. We also built an interactive chatbot for the students to promote self-learning.
 
We examined student learning processes and outcomes in the cybersecurity courses where students engaged in project-based learning using AISecKG. To holistically assess the impact of AISecKG, we collected data from (a) three different surveys (perceptions on AISecKG, uncertainty management, and learning motivation), (b) project scores, and (c) student interviews after each project. An aspect of cybersecurity education is related to uncertainty management in learning. We conceptualized a multidimensional uncertainty navigation disposition, including epistemic orientation toward uncertainty, self-efficacy in uncertainty navigation, and strategies for uncertainty navigation. Subsequently, we developed and validated a scale of uncertainty navigation disposition using a sample of around 500 university students for validating the reliable use in post-secondary computer science education contexts.

 
Regarding qualitative research, we examined student's perceptions of the usefulness of knowledge graphs and their exercise of epistemic agency in knowledge-graph-supported problem-based learning. The students reported that they perceived knowledge graphs as informative tools, visual references, and facilitators of access to just-in-time information. Students could better exercise their control over learning when they saw challenges as beneficial for future learning, understood and matched the instructor's expectations with their own, used strategies to manage their learning, and applied previous knowledge to the current problem.


Last Modified: 06/05/2024
Modified by: Huan Liu

Image
  • Cybersecurity Education Ontology
    Garima Agrawal
    Copyrighted
    Huan Liu
    AIsecKG
